awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: GEM--Asymmetric Entry and Transport of Magnetospheric Plasma During Periods of Northward Interplanetary Magnetic Field
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will investigate the transport of plasma from the solar wind into and through Earth's magnetosphere during intervals when the interplanetary magnetic field (IMF) has a northward orientation.  During periods of northward IMF the plasma within Earth's plasma sheet often is characterized by having two components, one hot and one relatively cold.  The cold component has a somewhat higher temperature on the dawn flank of the magnetosphere than on the dusk side and this suggests that the mechanism by which plasma enters the magnetosphere is not symmetric.  This project will use kinetic plasma simulations with the PLAsma Transport Numerical Magnetosphere Model (PLATNUMM) to investigate the plasma entry and transport mechanism.  The plasma simulations will be done using realistic magnetic and electric field models for northward IMF conditions.  The project will characterize the plasma phase space densities that develop in the layer connecting the magnetosphere with the magnetosheath.  The results of the simulation will be compared with observations of the plasma from spacecraft.  In addition, the project will simulate the plasma circulation within the plasma sheet in order to understand the asymmetries observed in the large-scale features.

Although periods of northward IMF are typically not periods of strong magnetic activity it is important to understand the evolution of the magnetically quiet times because they form the initial conditions that determine the dynamics of the magnetosphere during magnetically disturbed times.  Understanding the transition from magnetically quiet to disturbed times is important for our understanding of space weather phenomena that can impact humans and human engineered systems.  Much of the research will be carried out by a female graduate student and the project involves a collaboration between a university research program at UCLA and an independent research and development center (Aerospace Corporation).

This project investigated the transport of plasma (ionized gas) within the Earth's magnetosphere, with an emphasis on the region of the magnetosphere known as the magnetotail. The magnetotail is the region of the magnetosphere that is stretched outward away from the Sun, and the plasma within this region is referred to as the plasma sheet. The circulation of plasma in the magnetosphere can roughly be divided into two scenarios that are generally termed "quiet times" and "active times." During quiet times, the interplanetary magnetic field (IMF, an extension of the Sun's magnetitc field, that drives circulation of the magnetospheric plasma) points Northward, and during "active times" the IMF points Southward. In fact, "quiet times" makes it sound like very little is happening during periods of Northward IMF (NIMF), but actually this is a period in which the magnetosphere appears to absorb a lot of plasma from the Sun's solar wind.

The plasma in the Earth's plasma sheet is often found to consist of two components: a "hot" component and a "cold" component. The "cold" component is actually much, much hotter than temperatures commonly encountered on Earth. These two components are able to co-exist together in the magnetosphere for a long period of time (hours or tens of hours) because the plasma is "collisionless". On Earth, atmospheric densities are much higher than the plasma densities in the magnetosphere. As a result, it is not intuitive that gas or plasma with two different temperatures could coexist in the same location. However, in the magenosphere, this happens, and the result is called a two-component plasma. Is is believed that the cooler plasma has recently entered the magnetosphere from the solar wind, while the hotter plasma has been in the magnetosphere longer and has been energized through processes occurring in the magnetosphere.

Statistical observations from the magnetosphere allowed some researchers to investigate the evolution of these two components during periods of NIMF. Their results suggested that the longer the IMF is northward, the cooler the hot component of plasma becomes. Several processes might be able to explain that cooling. One is a mechanism that is analogous to evaporative cooling. The hottest plasma drifts faster than the cooler plasma, and it can leave the magnetosphere more quickly. The residual plasma is therefore colder. Eventually, the hot component might cool until it is no longer distinguishable from the cold component plasma. Another idea is that the plasma might cool through interactions with the cold component. This is analogous to conductive equilibrium, in which two objects of different temperatures that are in contact eventually come to thermal equilibrium at the same temperature (the hotter object cools, and the cooler object is heated). In the magnetosphere, the hot component is observed (statistically) to cool, but the cold component is not observed to warm. However, the magnetosphere is not a closed system, and during northward IMF cold plasma continues to enter the magnetosphere, so this mechanism still may be active.

We used simulations to examine whether gradient drift is sufficient to explain the cooling of the cold component. We developed the code necessary to simulate plasma drift, set up reasonably realistic electric and magnetic fields to drive those simulations, and we simulated various scenarios in an attempt to gain an understanding of whether the "evaporative cooling" mechanism could explain the observed cooling of the hot component of plasma in the plasma sheet. Our result indicated that the cooling is fast enough on the dawn half of the plasma sheet, but is too slow on the dusk half. However, because it is a simulation, there are certain uncertainties in our results.
